The percent elongation is a measure of a material's ductility, or its ability to deform plastically before fracturing, and is often used to characterize the behavior of a material in the plastic region of the stress-strain diagram.

The percent elongation is defined as the increase in length of a material specimen after it has been subjected to a tensile test, expressed as a percentage of the original length. It is typically calculated using the following formula:

% Elongation = (Final Length - Original Length) / Original Length x 100

In a stress-strain diagram, the percent elongation can be calculated by measuring the change in length of the specimen after it has undergone plastic deformation. The point at which plastic deformation begins can be identified on the stress-strain diagram as the yield point or the onset of non-linear deformation. The length of the specimen can be measured before and after the test using a ruler or other measuring instrument.

The percent elongation is an important material property that can be used to evaluate the suitability of a material for specific applications. For example, materials with high ductility and percent elongation may be preferred for applications where deformation before failure is desired, such as in structural components that are subject to high loads or impact. On the other hand, materials with low ductility and percent elongation may be preferred for applications where stiffness and rigidity are important, such as in precision instruments or machine components.
